List1.Meaning: deviating from the norm
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire found Luke’s aberrant behavior suspicious when he voluntarily cleaned his room.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s aberrant decision to get a spray tan ended in disaster.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s aberrant decision to attend Emily’s party without coffee shocked everyone.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s aberrant switch from trains to geology raised everyone's eyebrows.

List1.Meaning: to depart clandestinely; to steal off and hide
List1.Modern Family Example: Haley tried to abscond with Gloria’s heels before anyone noticed.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler tried to abscond from Janice’s birthday dinner.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lane tried to abscond from church to practice with her band.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj tried to abscond from a double date after it got awkward.

List1.Meaning: eager and enthusiastic willingness
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil accepted the open house task with alacrity, ready with brochures and balloons.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe accepted the weirdest jobs with alacrity—as long as they paid cash.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory jumped into her editorial duties with alacrity.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard volunteered with alacrity for a mission to the Arctic—until he heard Sheldon was coming.

List1.Meaning: deviation from the normal order or rule
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell was baffled by the anomaly of Lily willingly eating vegetables.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel’s sudden interest in paleontology was an anomaly even Ross couldn’t explain.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris viewed Rory’s late-night snacking during finals as a bizarre anomaly.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s interest in physics was an anomaly that left Sheldon suspicious.

List1.Meaning: an expression of approval
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam beamed with pride at the principal’s approbation for his school play.
List1.Friends Example: Monica basked in the approbation after organizing a perfect Thanksgiving dinner.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory received approbation from her professor for her insightful essay.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon beamed at the approbation from Stephen Hawking after solving a math error.

List1.Meaning: strenuous; requiring significant effort
List1.Modern Family Example: Carrying the groceries upstairs was an arduous task for Jay’s bad knee.
List1.Friends Example: Joey found reading the entire script in one night arduous.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai found navigating Chilton’s PTA politics arduous.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Fixing the elevator was an arduous task—mainly because no one wanted to try.

List1.Meaning: to ease or lessen; to appease or pacify
List1.Modern Family Example: To assuage Gloria’s anger, Jay bought her a necklace she didn’t even want.
List1.Friends Example: Ross bought a plush dinosaur to assuage Emma’s tantrum.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: To assuage Emily’s frustration, Lorelai agreed to another Friday night dinner.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: To assuage Amy’s disappointment, Sheldon gave her a hug and a contract amendment.

List1.Meaning: daring and fearless; recklessly bold
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam’s audacious performance of Beyoncé at the school function stunned everyone.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s audacious street performances sometimes drew police attention.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s audacious speech to the school board left everyone stunned.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s audacious magic tricks made Sheldon cringe during dinner.

List1.Meaning: without adornment; bare; simple
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell loved the austere elegance of the modern art exhibit, unlike Cam.
List1.Friends Example: Monica’s apartment had an austere charm—if you ignored her cleaning supplies.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s apartment had an austere vibe—one lamp and three shirts.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s room was decorated in the most austere fashion imaginable.

List1.Meaning: possessing self-evident truth
List1.Modern Family Example: Alex treated her top grades as axiomatic—hard work simply meant success.
List1.Friends Example: To Chandler, sarcasm was axiomatic—it required no explanation.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory believed it was axiomatic that books were better than people.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: To Sheldon, it was axiomatic that he should have his own bathroom schedule.

List1.Meaning: following or in agreement with accepted standards
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire’s strict rules were seen as canonical in the Dunphy household.
List1.Friends Example: Monica’s label-maker organization system was canonical among the group.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily maintained canonical traditions for every family holiday.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon insisted on canonical rules during Fun with Flags.

List1.Meaning: inclined to change one's mind impulsively
List1.Modern Family Example: Lily’s capricious decision to dye her hair purple gave Cam a mini breakdown.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel’s capricious career choices always left Ross worried.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s capricious decision to start an inn was met with skepticism.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s capricious dating decisions often left the gang confused.

List1.Meaning: to criticize severely
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay didn’t hesitate to censure Phil for ruining the new TV setup.
List1.Friends Example: Monica didn’t hesitate to censure Chandler for making a joke at her expense.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily didn’t hesitate to censure Lorelai for her unorthodox parenting.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon didn’t hesitate to censure Leonard for leaving the milk out.

List1.Meaning: trickery or subterfuge; deception
List1.Modern Family Example: Luke’s chicanery to get out of homework fooled Phil but not Claire.
List1.Friends Example: Joey used chicanery to sneak into a second audition round.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s chicanery in selling “invisible” sunscreen fooled only himself.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s chicanery about his Mars application fooled everyone but Bernadette.

List1.Meaning: an informed and astute judge in matters of taste
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell considered himself a wine connoisseur after one Napa Valley trip.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel thought of herself as a fashion connoisseur, especially at Bloomingdale's.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Sookie was a connoisseur of pastries and dinner rolls.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy considered herself a connoisseur of vintage neurobiology texts.

List1.Meaning: complex or complicated
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam’s explanation of his wedding seating chart was so convoluted even Gloria got lost.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler’s excuse for being late was so convoluted even Joey gave up following.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s logic for why she should be prom queen was convoluted and terrifying.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s explanation of roommate responsibilities was convoluted even with diagrams.

List1.Meaning: to undeceive; to set right
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire tried to disabuse Luke of the idea that he could become a billionaire from gaming.
List1.Friends Example: Ross tried to disabuse Rachel of the idea that dinosaurs were just big lizards.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai tried to disabuse Rory of the belief that Yale would be easy.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy tried to disabuse Sheldon of the idea that emotions were illogical.

List1.Meaning: conflicting; dissonant or harsh in sound
List1.Modern Family Example: Manny’s poetry clashed with the discordant sounds of Jay’s construction tools.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s new song was so discordant that even she winced at one point.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s disco-themed party felt discordant in the quaint Stars Hollow setting.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: The discordant sound of Sheldon’s theremin practice drove Penny insane.

List1.Meaning: fundamentally distinct or dissimilar
List1.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s approach to parenting was disparate from Jay’s old-school methods.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s views on relationships were disparate from Joey’s 'food and hugs' method.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory and Jess had disparate views on romance—she read poetry, he made sarcastic remarks.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s views on friendship were disparate from Leonard’s idea of fun.

List1.Meaning: extreme boldness; presumptuousness
List1.Modern Family Example: Lily had the effrontery to ask for cake after throwing her vegetables on the floor.
List1.Friends Example: Joey had the effrontery to ask for Monica’s last cookie without shame.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris had the effrontery to correct the professor in front of the class.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard had the effrontery to bring Bernadette to a gaming night uninvited.

List1.Meaning: well-spoken; expressive; articulate
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire gave an eloquent speech about motherhood at the PTA meeting.
List1.Friends Example: Ross delivered an eloquent speech at Carol’s wedding.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s eloquent defense of her thesis stunned the committee.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s eloquent toast surprised everyone—especially Sheldon.

List1.Meaning: to weaken; to reduce in vitality
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil felt enervated after a long day of real estate showings and trampoline incidents.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler felt enervated after a night of Joey’s snoring and hugging.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai felt enervated after dealing with three events and two tantrums in one day.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj felt enervated after carrying all the Comic-Con loot back home.

List1.Meaning: dissatisfaction and restlessness from boredom
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam’s ennui peaked when Mitchell made him clean instead of rehearse.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel’s ennui at work led her to redesign the coffee menu instead.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s ennui led her to wander around Stars Hollow instead of studying.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s ennui led him to rearrange the periodic table tiles again.

List1.Meaning: to use ambiguous language with deceptive intent
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell accused Cam of equivocating when he claimed he didn’t ‘technically’ break the vase.
List1.Friends Example: Monica equivocated when asked who broke the wedding gift.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai equivocated when Emily asked where the money went.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard equivocated when Penny asked if her acting was improving.

List1.Meaning: very learned; scholarly
List1.Modern Family Example: Alex's erudite answer during trivia night left even Jay speechless.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s erudite monologues made everyone sleepy except Phoebe—who just zoned out.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s erudite comment during the town meeting impressed even Taylor.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s erudite answer stunned the science podcast host.

List1.Meaning: to clear of blame; vindicate
List1.Modern Family Example: Luke was exculpated when the camera revealed it was the dog that made the mess.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler was exculpated when security footage showed it was Joey who unplugged the fridge.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was exculpated after Kirk admitted he’d double-booked the wedding venue.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard was exculpated when it turned out the experiment failure was a lab bug.

List1.Meaning: urgent; requiring immediate action
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire saw it as exigent to fix the Wi-Fi before the kids revolted.
List1.Friends Example: Monica declared it exigent to deep clean after discovering a single crumb.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily saw it as exigent to immediately repair the garden path before the guests arrived.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard declared it exigent to find new batteries before D&D night began.

List1.Meaning: improvised; done without preparation
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam gave an extemporaneous toast at the wedding and somehow made it about himself.
List1.Friends Example: Joey’s extemporaneous audition monologue involved pizza and crime-fighting turtles.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai gave an extemporaneous speech at the inn’s opening that brought tears.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon gave an extemporaneous lecture to strangers at a bus stop.

List1.Meaning: intentional obstruction through long speeches
List1.Modern Family Example: Gloria threatened to filibuster the HOA meeting until they allowed flamingo decorations.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe joked about filibustering the friends’ vote on movie night.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily launched a filibuster about floral arrangements at the wedding planner meeting.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy joked about launching a filibuster if the girls' night was canceled again.

List1.Meaning: to loudly attack or denounce
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell fulminated against the school board for canceling the spring musical.
List1.Friends Example: Ross fulminated against the museum director for replacing his exhibit with a giant squid.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris fulminated when Rory made editor over her at Yale.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon fulminated about the misuse of the word “literally” in modern English.

List1.Meaning: artless; frank; candid
List1.Modern Family Example: Lily’s ingenuous explanation about her missing homework melted even Mitchell’s heart.
List1.Friends Example: Joey’s ingenuous belief in Santa Claus was somehow still intact.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s ingenuous defense of Logan made Lorelai raise an eyebrow.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s ingenuous belief in romantic comedies shaped all his relationships.

List1.Meaning: accustomed to accepting something undesirable
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil was inured to rejection after years in real estate.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel became inured to weird dates after a dozen blind setups by her mother.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was inured to Kirk’s odd behavior after years of unpredictable stunts.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon became inured to Howard’s jokes—he barely flinched by season six.

List1.Meaning: easily angered; irritable
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay’s irascible reaction to broken golf clubs terrified even the dog.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s irascible reaction to being corrected made even Monica blink.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s irascible mood made the maids quit—again.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s irascible response to a misaligned whiteboard marker ruined the group mood.

List1.Meaning: to praise highly
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire lauded Alex’s academic achievements at the school board meeting.
List1.Friends Example: Monica lauded Chandler for fixing the faucet—until it exploded again.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory lauded her grandmother’s support in her Yale application essay.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard lauded Penny for finally watching *Star Trek* without complaining.

List1.Meaning: clear; easily understood; limpid
List1.Modern Family Example: Alex gave a lucid explanation of quantum physics to her clueless siblings.
List1.Friends Example: Ross gave a lucid explanation of evolution that no one really asked for.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory gave a lucid explanation of her thesis to the Yale panel.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s lucid explanation of quantum entanglement impressed no one but Leonard.

List1.Meaning: the quality of being generously noble in mind and heart, especially in forgiving
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam showed magnanimity by forgiving a rival teacher who stole his play idea.
List1.Friends Example: Monica showed magnanimity by inviting Janice to Thanksgiving—briefly.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai showed magnanimity by forgiving Emily after their heated fight.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard showed magnanimity by forgiving Sheldon for crashing his presentation.

List1.Meaning: associated with war and the armed forces
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay's martial storytelling style made his army days sound like epic battles.
List1.Friends Example: Joey mistook a martial arts class for a good acting gig prep.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai joked that Friday night dinners were like martial drills.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s love of martial law board games annoyed everyone on game night.

List1.Meaning: of the world; typical of or concerned with the ordinary; commonplace
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil's mundane task of fixing the sprinkler turned into a backyard flood.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel quit her mundane job to pursue fashion dreams.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory complained that her life felt too mundane without Yale drama.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny found Sheldon’s obsession with flags to be mundanely repetitive.

List1.Meaning: coming into being; in early developmental stages; incipient
List1.Modern Family Example: Lily’s nascent fashion blog started with a glitter-filled homepage.
List1.Friends Example: Joey’s nascent interest in sailing sank after five minutes of rowing.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s nascent interest in journalism blossomed at the school paper.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s nascent research on brain waves sparked Sheldon’s interest.

List1.Meaning: vague; cloudy; lacking clearly defined form; hazy
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell found Cam’s explanation for the broken vase nebulous at best.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s logic was often nebulous but somehow made sense to her.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s explanation of the DAR rules was so nebulous even Lorelai spaced out.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s explanation of his love life was as nebulous as his plans.

List1.Meaning: a new word, expression, or usage; the creation or use of new words or senses
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam proudly coined a neologism for his latest dessert creation—'cupcakookie'.
List1.Friends Example: Joey coined a neologism—‘moo point’—to explain pointless arguments.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai coined a neologism to describe her coffee obsession—‘caffecrazy.’
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon introduced a neologism to describe roommate violations—‘spot-trespass.’

List1.Meaning: harmful; injurious; pernicious
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay found Gloria's noxious perfume so overpowering that he opened all the windows.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler complained about the noxious fumes from Joey’s cologne sample testing.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily considered Lorelai’s taste in music noxious to civilized society.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s noxious lab chemicals cleared the floor of interns.

List1.Meaning: lacking sharpness of intellect; not clear or precise in thought or expression
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil’s obtuse understanding of technology resulted in deleting their home videos.
List1.Friends Example: Joey’s obtuse comment during trivia night cost them the win.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Jess gave an obtuse answer when Rory asked if he cared about school.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s obtuse questions about physics made Sheldon twitch.

List1.Meaning: to anticipate and make unnecessary
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire set reminders to obviate another forgotten anniversary.
List1.Friends Example: Ross created backup plans to obviate any wedding disasters.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai ordered food early to obviate a meltdown at Friday dinner.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard brought snacks early to obviate Sheldon’s mealtime complaints.

List1.Meaning: troubling; burdensome
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam found organizing the school musical an onerous burden after week three.
List1.Friends Example: Monica found planning Thanksgiving for 12 people incredibly onerous.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Running the inn became an onerous task when the staff all caught the flu.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon considered Amy’s birthday plans an onerous social task.

List1.Meaning: a song or hymn of praise and thanksgiving
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell sang a heartfelt paean to Lily during her adoption celebration.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe composed a paean for her mom’s birthday and performed it on her guitar.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory wrote a paean to literature in her graduation speech.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard composed a paean to space travel after his return from the ISS.

List1.Meaning: a humorous imitation intended for ridicule or comic effect, especially in literature and art
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil made a parody video of Jay's BBQ tutorial, complete with slow-mo sauce shots.
List1.Friends Example: Ross made a parody of Joey’s audition tape, complete with fake tears.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s parody of Taylor’s welcome speech had the whole town laughing.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: The gang made a parody video of Sheldon’s Fun with Flags series.

List1.Meaning: recurrent through the year or many years; happening repeatedly
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam’s perennial complaint about school budget cuts made Mitchell sigh annually.
List1.Friends Example: Gunther’s perennial love for Rachel never wavered.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s perennial grumpiness became part of Stars Hollow charm.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s perennial fear of germs was well-documented.

List1.Meaning: intentional breach of faith; treachery
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire considered Luke’s betrayal of his study group a small act of perfidy.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel saw Ross’s kiss with Chloe as a major act of perfidy.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory saw Logan’s secret party as a small act of perfidy.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard saw Sheldon’s password change as an act of perfidy.

List1.Meaning: cursory; done without care or interest; done superficially
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil gave a perfunctory nod when Claire explained how to use the washing machine.
List1.Friends Example: Joey gave a perfunctory wave after winning an award he didn’t understand.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s perfunctory nod was enough to stop Emily mid-rant.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj gave a perfunctory apology after spilling coffee on the server.

List1.Meaning: acutely perceptive; having keen discernment
List1.Modern Family Example: Alex’s perspicacious insights made her the favorite of her philosophy professor.
List1.Friends Example: Monica’s perspicacious comment saved Rachel from buying a terrible outfit.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s perspicacious critiques scared even seasoned professors.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s perspicacious observation cracked the neurology case wide open.

List1.Meaning: to babble meaninglessly; to talk in an empty and idle manner
List1.Modern Family Example: Lily continued to prattle on about unicorns while Cam tried to nap.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe would prattle endlessly about her dream journal.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Babette would prattle endlessly about her cat’s emotional needs.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard would prattle about space toilets whenever nervous.

List1.Meaning: acting with excessive haste or impulse
List1.Modern Family Example: Haley’s precipitate decision to dye her hair blue backfired during picture day.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel’s precipitate decision to move to Paris caused emotional chaos.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s precipitate decision to propose startled even Rory.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny made a precipitate decision to cut her hair before a date.

List1.Meaning: to cause or happen before anticipated or required
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire’s warning about the storm precipitated a panicked grocery run.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s phone call to Emily precipitated their final breakup.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s pressure precipitated Rory’s decision to debut in society.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s knock precipitated a very awkward hallway encounter.

List1.Meaning: a disposition in favor of something; preference; a special liking
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay had a predilection for old Westerns, even quoting them at the dinner table.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler had a predilection for sarcastic one-liners in emotional moments.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory had a predilection for classic novels over modern bestsellers.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon had a predilection for spaghetti on Thursdays—no exceptions.

List1.Meaning: foreknowledge of events; knowing of events prior to their occurring
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell’s prescience about rain saved Cam’s outdoor party plans.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s prescience about Rachel’s job offer turned out eerily accurate.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s prescience about the weather saved the inn's garden party.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s prescience about Sheldon’s Nobel obsession proved accurate.

List1.Meaning: to deliberately avoid the truth; to mislead
List1.Modern Family Example: Luke tried to prevaricate when Claire asked about the missing cookies.
List1.Friends Example: Joey tried to prevaricate about eating the wedding cake early.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Jess tried to prevaricate when Luke asked about his school attendance.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj tried to prevaricate when confronted about his online date fiasco.

List1.Meaning: misgivings; reservations; causes for hesitancy; doubts
List1.Modern Family Example: Haley had no qualms about asking for a last-minute allowance increase.
List1.Friends Example: Monica had no qualms about enforcing her towel-folding rules.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory had no qualms about missing a party to finish a book.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard had no qualms about lying to avoid brunch with Beverly.

List1.Meaning: to retract, especially a previously held belief
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam refused to recant his belief that he was born to be on stage.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel decided to recant her decision and stay in New York.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris recanted her opinion on the student council—barely.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon recanted his stance on social interaction—temporarily.

List1.Meaning: to disprove; to successfully argue against
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire tried to refute Jay’s argument about parenting with actual statistics.
List1.Friends Example: Ross tried to refute every point during the infamous 'we were on a break' debate.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai tried to refute Emily’s claim that she never cared about tradition.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy refuted Sheldon’s claim about her not being romantic with a spreadsheet.

List1.Meaning: to forcibly assign, especially to a lower place or position
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil was relegated to sleeping in the guest room after his magic trick failed again.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler was relegated to sleeping on the couch after his gym joke bombed.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Michel was relegated to door duty after complaining one too many times.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard was relegated to couch duty after breaking Bernadette’s vase.

List1.Meaning: quiet; reserved; reluctant to express thoughts and feelings
List1.Modern Family Example: Alex was reticent to admit she didn’t understand the new math topic.
List1.Friends Example: Ross was reticent about discussing his failed marriages.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke was reticent to express his feelings for Lorelai for seasons.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was reticent about revealing his childhood diary entries.

List1.Meaning: concerned and attentive; eager
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam was solicitous of Mitchell after he had a rough day at work.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe was solicitous of Rachel during her pregnancy mood swings.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was solicitous of Rory when she got rejected from Harvard.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy was solicitous of Sheldon after he failed to win the grant.

List1.Meaning: characterized by filth, grime, or squalor; foul
List1.Modern Family Example: Gloria called the bachelor party’s hotel room too sordid for even Jay.
List1.Friends Example: Joey’s apartment got so sordid Monica refused to even walk in.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: The apartment Kirk rented was so sordid even Miss Patty screamed.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s apartment became so sordid after his breakup, even Cinnamon judged him.

List1.Meaning: occurring only occasionally, or in scattered instances
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil’s attempts to fix the fence happened sporadically over six months.
List1.Friends Example: Ross’s romantic gestures appeared sporadic but were genuinely heartfelt.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s calls to Lorelai became sporadic after moving into Yale.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s hobbies were sporadic, from trains to medieval lore.

List1.Meaning: to waste by spending or using irresponsibly
List1.Modern Family Example: Luke squandered his allowance on useless gadgets again.
List1.Friends Example: Joey squandered his soap opera money on a boat he couldn’t sail.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk squandered his paycheck on bizarre inventions weekly.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard squandered his paycheck on a Batman belt.

List1.Meaning: not moving, active, or in motion; at rest; stationary
List1.Modern Family Example: Jay remained static on the couch until the football game ended.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler remained static during a deep conversation—until the pizza arrived.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s static diner decor never changed in two decades.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: The elevator remained static for 12 years—until the finale.

List1.Meaning: to stun, baffle, or amaze; bewilder; confuse
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil was stupefied when Claire actually laughed at one of his puns.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel was stupefied when she saw her sister dating Ross.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily was stupefied when Rory turned down the internship.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was stupefied when he got applause at a party.

List1.Meaning: to block; thwart
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire's plan to surprise Jay was stymied by Luke spilling the beans.
List1.Friends Example: Monica’s plan to propose was stymied by her own emotional breakdown.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s plans for the festival were stymied by a permit issue.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s surprise visit stymied Sheldon’s bathroom schedule.

List1.Meaning: the combination of parts to make a whole
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam’s recipe was a synthesis of his Midwestern roots and Gloria’s spice cabinet.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s wedding song was a synthesis of love, weird lyrics, and jazz hands.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s life was a synthesis of chaos, coffee, and unconditional love.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Their research was a synthesis of physics, engineering, and sarcasm.

List1.Meaning: a force that causes rotation
List1.Modern Family Example: Phil struggled to understand the torque needed for the DIY garage door project.
List1.Friends Example: Ross explained torque using dinosaurs and a toy truck—confusing everyone.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke explained torque while fixing the diner’s broken coffee machine to a completely uninterested Rory.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon went into detail explaining torque—using a whiteboard and three Lego models.

List1.Meaning: winding; twisting; excessively complicated
List1.Modern Family Example: Cam described his journey through the school bureaucracy as tortuous and exhausting.
List1.Friends Example: Monica’s tortuous recipe instructions made Joey give up and order pizza.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s tortuous logic during the student council debate made the teacher need aspirin.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard found Sheldon’s tortuous explanation of string theory exhausting.

List1.Meaning: fierce and cruel; eager to fight
List1.Modern Family Example: Gloria's truculent defense of Manny’s school project scared off the PTA moms.
List1.Friends Example: Rachel’s truculent response to Ross’s list had everyone backing away slowly.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily's truculent tone during Friday dinners often made Lorelai skip dessert.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s truculent response to someone sitting in his spot caused a scene at the comic book store.

List1.Meaning: truthfulness; honesty; authenticity
List1.Modern Family Example: Mitchell's veracity during the deposition impressed even the opposing lawyer.
List1.Friends Example: Phoebe’s veracity about her weird past was both refreshing and terrifying.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s veracity in her journalism impressed even her toughest professor.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy admired Sheldon’s veracity during their awkward but honest relationship discussions.

List1.Meaning: extremely harmful or poisonous; bitterly hostile or antagonistic
List1.Modern Family Example: Claire called Gloria’s chili ‘virulent’ after one bite set off a five-alarm fire in her mouth.
List1.Friends Example: Monica warned that the leftovers Joey left out had become virulent overnight.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily described Lorelai’s attitude as virulent during their DAR argument.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: The virulent bacteria Howard left in the fridge caused a lab lockdown.

List1.Meaning: having an insatiable appetite for an activity or pursuit; ravenous
List1.Modern Family Example: Haley had a voracious appetite for social media likes and attention.
List1.Friends Example: Joey had a voracious hunger for sandwiches—especially meatball subs.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai had a voracious craving for coffee—morning, noon, and night.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon had a voracious appetite for knowledge—especially theoretical physics.

List1.Meaning: to move to and fro; to sway; to be unsettled in opinion
List1.Modern Family Example: Luke began to waver about his science fair topic after seeing Manny’s presentation.
List1.Friends Example: Chandler began to waver about the wedding after listening to Ross’s advice.
List1.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory began to waver about attending Harvard after visiting Yale.
List1.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj began to waver about his crush on Penny after she laughed at his poetry.

List2.Meaning: to lessen in intensity or degree
List2.Modern Family Example: Claire waited for her frustration to abate before discussing the family vacation plans with Phil.
List2.Friends Example: Ross hoped his embarrassment would abate after yelling 'We were on a break!' in front of everyone.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai waited for Emily’s anger to abate before bringing up the topic of Friday night dinners again.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon waited for his irritation to abate before talking to Leonard about moving his spot on the couch.

List2.Modern Family Example: Cam received an accolade at school for directing the most dramatic kindergarten play ever.
List2.Friends Example: Joey mistook the sarcastic laugh of the director as an accolade for his acting.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory received an accolade from her literature professor for her insightful essay on Dostoevsky.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon reluctantly accepted the accolade after winning the physics award—only after confirming its prestige.

List2.Modern Family Example: Phil basked in the adulation of his fans after his cheesy magic trick went viral online.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel was overwhelmed by the adulation she received from her coworkers after organizing the fashion show.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was uncomfortable with the adulation she received after winning the student council election.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard basked in the adulation from comic-con fans who recognized his astronaut badge.

List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell criticized the party decorations, claiming they didn’t match his minimalist aesthetic.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel refused to let Joey decorate the apartment because his aesthetic was ‘early pizza box.’
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s quirky aesthetic was evident in every inch of the Dragonfly Inn’s decor.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy tried to enhance Sheldon’s wardrobe with a new aesthetic, which he immediately rejected.

List2.Modern Family Example: To ameliorate the tension at dinner, Gloria told a hilarious story about Jay’s first attempt at salsa dancing.
List2.Friends Example: To ameliorate Monica’s stress, Chandler cleaned the entire apartment—even under the couch cushions.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: To ameliorate the awkwardness after a fight, Rory baked cookies for Lorelai.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: To ameliorate tension after an argument, Leonard brought Penny Chinese takeout and an apology.

List2.Modern Family Example: Jay couldn’t understand Cam’s temporary ascetic lifestyle of no meat, no dairy, and no drama.
List2.Friends Example: Ross tried an ascetic diet to impress a date, but gave up after smelling Joey’s meatball sub.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s ascetic lifestyle contrasted sharply with Lorelai’s coffee-fueled spontaneity.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s ascetic lifestyle included a rigid schedule and absolutely no caffeine after 3 PM.

List2.Modern Family Example: Haley’s avarice became obvious when she started charging Lily for makeup tips.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s avarice was evident when he hid extra food from the set in his coat pockets.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s avarice surfaced when he tried to raise the rent on all the town square shops.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s avarice kicked in when he saw how much his rare comic book was worth online.

List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell believed in the axiom that ‘less is more’—except when it came to throw pillows.
List2.Friends Example: Chandler lived by the axiom that sarcasm was the answer to everything.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai lived by the axiom that coffee solves everything.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: For Sheldon, it was an axiom that friendship contracts should be taken seriously.

List2.Modern Family Example: Cam’s description of his bucolic hometown included cows, quilts, and church picnics.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe found peace in a bucolic park where she wrote her songs about trees and sandwiches.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Stars Hollow had a bucolic charm that made visitors feel like they stepped into a postcard.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny found the bucolic life of Nebraska boring compared to the chaos of Pasadena.

List2.Modern Family Example: Lily’s confidence began to burgeon after receiving praise for her fashion sense.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel’s career began to burgeon after she landed a major role at Ralph Lauren.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s confidence began to burgeon during her time at Yale.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Bernadette’s career began to burgeon after she secured a major pharmaceutical deal.

List2.Meaning: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
List2.Modern Family Example: The family dinner turned into a cacophony of voices, clashing opinions, and dropped silverware.
List2.Friends Example: The sound of Joey’s singing, Chandler’s sarcasm, and Phoebe’s guitar created a true cacophony.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The town meeting erupted into a cacophony of overlapping complaints and suggestions.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: The cacophony in the comic book store on game release night was unbearable for Sheldon.

List2.Modern Family Example: Jay considered grilling on Sundays a sacred part of his personal canon.
List2.Friends Example: To Ross, correcting grammar was part of the scientific canon.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: At the book club, Rory insisted that 'Pride and Prejudice' was a foundational part of the literary canon.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon insisted that anything not written by the original Star Trek writers was not canon.

List2.Modern Family Example: Claire’s castigation of Luke for blowing up the microwave was both epic and loud.
List2.Friends Example: Monica’s castigation of Chandler for using her best towels as rags was swift and severe.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s castigation of Lorelai’s life choices came with a side of perfectly folded linen napkins.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s castigation of Leonard for touching his whiteboard was dramatic and oddly Shakespearean.

List2.Modern Family Example: Lily’s unexpected question about babies was the catalyst for a full family debate on parenting.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel’s pregnancy announcement was the catalyst for Ross to reevaluate his life choices—again.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Max’s proposal was the unexpected catalyst for Lorelai to reexamine her life.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s arrival was the catalyst that disrupted the boys’ perfectly nerdy ecosystem.

List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell’s caustic comments about Cam’s costume choice didn’t go unnoticed.
List2.Friends Example: Chandler’s caustic sense of humor often got him into trouble—especially with Janice.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris's caustic remarks during class debates often left classmates in stunned silence.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s caustic remarks about Howard’s engineering degree never failed to sting.

List2.Modern Family Example: Phil was chary about letting Luke borrow his drone after the last crash incident.
List2.Friends Example: Ross was chary about letting Joey touch his fossils after the 'accidental' T-Rex nose break.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was chary of asking her parents for help, knowing it would come with strings attached.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard was chary about letting Sheldon borrow his car after the ‘parking incident.’

List2.Modern Family Example: Alex gave a cogent argument on why she deserved a new laptop—and she won.
List2.Friends Example: Monica presented a cogent case for making Thanksgiving dinner her way—again.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory gave a cogent argument on why she should attend Chilton, and Lorelai relented.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy made a cogent argument for why their experiment needed more test subjects.

List2.Modern Family Example: Luke’s complaisance meant he always went along with Manny’s bizarre schemes.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s complaisance made him say yes to three auditions in one day—even if one was for a mime.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lane’s complaisance made her agree to a blind date set up by her mother—even though she dreaded it.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s complaisance often led him to agree with whatever plan Howard came up with—however absurd.

List2.Meaning: causing or likely to cause an argument
List2.Modern Family Example: Dinner turned contentious when Jay mentioned politics and Gloria joined in passionately.
List2.Friends Example: Every group decision about where to eat became a contentious debate led by Monica.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Friday dinners often turned contentious between Lorelai and Emily over the smallest things.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Game night grew contentious when Sheldon insisted on playing by 'Sheldon’s revised rules.'

List2.Modern Family Example: Cam was contrite after forgetting Mitchell’s birthday—especially after the silent treatment began.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe was genuinely contrite after accidentally giving Joey the wrong love advice.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was contrite after missing Lorelai’s graduation to visit Jess in New York.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard felt contrite after mocking Raj’s date... in front of her.

List2.Modern Family Example: All signs pointed to Luke as the culpable party behind the broken vase.
List2.Friends Example: Chandler looked culpable after Monica’s label maker mysteriously disappeared.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk was clearly culpable when the town’s Christmas lights short-circuited—again.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard was clearly culpable for deleting Sheldon’s DVR recordings.

List2.Meaning: a scarcity or lack of something
List2.Modern Family Example: There was a dearth of snacks at Lily’s playdate, much to the dismay of Phil.
List2.Friends Example: Joey complained about the dearth of meatball subs at Monica’s healthy dinner.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: There was a dearth of fresh coffee at the inn, sending Lorelai into panic mode.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: There was a dearth of snacks during Halo night, leading to a full-blown crisis.

List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell had to demur when Cam suggested turning their backyard into a llama sanctuary.
List2.Friends Example: Ross demurred when Rachel suggested naming their daughter 'Rainy Sparkle'.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory demurred when asked to criticize a fellow student’s writing during workshop.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy demurred when Penny asked if she wanted a girls' night involving tequila shots.

List2.Modern Family Example: Alex’s didactic tone about climate change bored the entire family by dessert.
List2.Friends Example: Ross’s didactic explanation of dinosaurs made even Ben yawn.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s didactic speeches during class often overshadowed the teacher.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s didactic monologues often turned what could have been jokes into science lectures.

List2.Meaning: careful about what one says or does
List2.Modern Family Example: Claire showed great discretion by not telling the kids about Phil’s failed invention idea.
List2.Friends Example: Monica lacked discretion when she blurted out Rachel’s secret in front of everyone.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Michel showed discretion when he quietly handled a guest complaint without alarming Lorelai.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Bernadette used great discretion when telling Howard’s mom about his failed invention.

List2.Modern Family Example: Gloria acted as a disinterested judge during the family's salsa dance contest.
List2.Friends Example: Gunther, disinterested and detached, was the only one who could fairly judge the trifle bake-off.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke acted as a disinterested mediator during one of Taylor’s town hall meltdowns.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny was disinterested in the Dungeons & Dragons game but watched out of loyalty.

List2.Meaning: inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam was dogmatic about his holiday traditions—no deviations allowed.
List2.Friends Example: Ross became dogmatic when debating evolution, turning dinner into a lecture.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily was dogmatic about traditions—especially when it came to formal dinners.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was dogmatic about the proper method to load a dishwasher.

List2.Modern Family Example: Lily’s ebullience was contagious when she put on her sparkly princess dress.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe’s ebullience lit up Central Perk every time she sang about her weirdest dreams.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s ebullience filled the room when she talked about snow or coffee.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s ebullience during his planetarium presentations was surprisingly contagious.

List2.Meaning: deriving ideas from a diverse range of sources
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam and Mitchell’s home decor was a beautiful yet eclectic mix of patterns and colors.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe’s eclectic wardrobe often included boas, boots, and a banana pin.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The inn’s eclectic furniture choices gave it a warm and unique vibe.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: The apartment’s decor was an eclectic mix of Star Wars posters and physics plaques.

List2.Modern Family Example: Manny wrote an emotional elegy for his goldfish that made everyone tear up.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe composed a hilarious yet touching elegy for her mom’s cat.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory wrote a heartfelt elegy for Richard after his passing.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard wrote an elegy for his broken lab equipment after a failed experiment.

List2.Modern Family Example: After a sunburn at the beach, Phil applied a cooling emollient cream—then screamed anyway.
List2.Friends Example: Monica’s favorite emollient lotion was off-limits—but Chandler used it anyway.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai handed Rory an emollient cream after a disastrous tanning incident.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy suggested an emollient cream when Sheldon got a rash from his lab coat.

List2.Modern Family Example: Alex insisted on empirical data before switching to a new science fair project.
List2.Friends Example: Ross wouldn’t accept Joey’s ghost story without empirical evidence.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris demanded empirical evidence before trusting a new study method.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon insisted on empirical evidence before accepting any of Howard’s theories.

List2.Modern Family Example: Lily’s smile was enigmatic as she quietly walked out holding Cam’s phone.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe’s lyrics were so enigmatic, no one knew if ‘Sticky Shoes’ was happy or sad.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Jess remained an enigmatic figure, often disappearing without explanation.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy found Sheldon’s behavior enigmatic—especially when he showed emotion.

List2.Meaning: lasting for a very short time
List2.Modern Family Example: Phil’s mustache was an ephemeral experiment—gone in a day, forgotten in an hour.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel’s relationship with Tag was passionate but ephemeral.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s job at the newspaper turned out to be more ephemeral than she’d hoped.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s romantic relationships were often passionate but ephemeral.

List2.Meaning: intended for or understood by a small, specific group; abstruse; difficult to understany
List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell’s esoteric legal jokes went over everyone’s head at the family dinner.
List2.Friends Example: Ross’s lecture on trilobites was so esoteric that even Chandler fell asleep.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s esoteric reference to 18th-century French literature left even Paris confused.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s esoteric discussion of string theory bored everyone at the comic book store.

List2.Meaning: ‘@ speech honoring the dead (verb form: eulogize); panegyric; encomium
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam delivered a dramatic eulogy for their pet fish, complete with organ music.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe tried to sing a eulogy for her dead plant, turning it into a full song.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai gave a heartfelt eulogy for her broken coffee maker.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy wrote a surprisingly moving eulogy for a retired lab rat.

List2.Meaning: to remove blame; exculpate; acquit; vindicate
List2.Modern Family Example: Luke was exonerated when the real culprit behind the broken vase turned out to be the dog.
List2.Friends Example: Joey was exonerated after Monica realized it was Chandler who ate the last slice of cheesecake.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was exonerated when it turned out Paris had made the printing error in the Yale paper.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard was exonerated after Sheldon realized he himself misplaced the data.

List2.Modern Family Example: Phil’s facetious tone during a serious conversation confused Claire completely.
List2.Friends Example: Chandler was always facetious, especially when things got too emotional.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s facetious comments during Friday dinner drove Emily up the wall.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s facetious joke during the Mars rover presentation almost cost him his job.

List2.Meaning: an invalid or incorrect notion; a mistaken belief (adj. form: fallacious)
List2.Modern Family Example: Jay believed the fallacy that older people can’t learn technology—until he mastered the smart TV.
List2.Friends Example: Ross corrected Joey’s fallacy that ‘Jurassic’ meant ‘big and scary’.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily corrected the fallacy that good parenting requires weekly phone calls.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj pointed out the fallacy in Howard’s logic about black holes and donuts.

List2.Meaning: marked by stealth; covert; surreptitious; clandestine
List2.Modern Family Example: Haley gave a furtive glance at her phone while pretending to listen to Claire’s lecture.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel made a furtive exit after spilling coffee all over her date’s shirt.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lane made furtive attempts to sneak rock CDs past her mother.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon cast furtive glances at Amy’s dessert, trying not to ask for a bite.

List2.Meaning: _| sociable; outgoing; enjoying the company of other people
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam’s gregarious nature made him the star of every neighborhood party.
List2.Friends Example: Joey was the most gregarious of the group, instantly befriending everyone on set.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s gregarious charm lit up every room she walked into.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard was the most gregarious at Comic-Con, chatting with everyone in costume.

List2.Meaning: violating accepted dogma or convention (noun form: heresy)
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam considered it heretical to suggest that anyone else could cook Thanksgiving dinner better than him.
List2.Friends Example: To Monica, skipping Thanksgiving dinner was a heretical idea.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s idea to skip Christmas dinner was heretical to Emily.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: It was heretical to Sheldon when Leonard suggested Star Wars wasn’t perfect.

List2.Meaning: an exaggerated statement, often used as a figure of speech (adj. form: hyperbolic)
List2.Modern Family Example: Phil used such hyperbole to sell a house that he described a closet as ‘a portal to Narnia.’
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s acting stories were full of hyperbole, especially the one about Al Pacino’s butt double.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory claimed Chilton assigned ‘a thousand pages a night,’ an obvious hyperbole.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon used hyperbole to claim he’d die if he missed Fun with Flags.

List2.Meaning: | lacking funds; without money; indigent; penurious; destitute
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam joked that he was impecunious after buying expensive costumes for Lily’s school play.
List2.Friends Example: Joey was so impecunious he offered hugs as rent payment.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai often joked about being impecunious while running the inn.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj pretended to be impecunious to avoid splitting a group check.

List2.Meaning: beginning to come into being or to become apparent
List2.Modern Family Example: Claire noticed the incipient mess in the kitchen and sighed—another disaster was coming.
List2.Friends Example: Ross saw the incipient panic in Rachel’s eyes when she realized she’d lost her passport.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai noticed the incipient panic in Rory’s eyes before her big test.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy sensed Sheldon’s incipient jealousy when she laughed at Leonard’s joke.

List2.Modern Family Example: Phil was inert on the couch after chasing the dog around the yard all day.
List2.Friends Example: Joey was completely inert after eating an entire Thanksgiving turkey by himself.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: After a long day at the inn, Lorelai lay inert on the couch with coffee.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was inert for hours after being bested in a trivia contest.

List2.Modern Family Example: Lily’s innocuous prank turned into chaos when Jay slipped on the confetti.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel’s innocuous comment about a haircut spiraled into a full-blown fight.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s innocuous question turned into a heated family debate.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s innocuous comment about physics sparked a ten-minute correction from Sheldon.

List2.Meaning: to obtain by deception or flattery
List2.Modern Family Example: Gloria managed to inveigle Jay into adopting another dog by using Lily’s pouty face.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe inveigled her way into a gig by telling the manager she was part of a 'spiritual band.'
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai inveigled Sookie into baking two cakes instead of one by complimenting her frosting.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard inveigled Raj into building his robot by promising to name it after him.

List2.Modern Family Example: Alex was morose after losing the debate championship despite her flawless argument.
List2.Friends Example: Ross looked morose for days after finding out Marcel had been sent to a zoo in another country.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was morose after her breakup with Logan.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard looked morose every time Sheldon ‘borrowed’ his whiteboard.

List2.Modern Family Example: Claire found the idea of Phil installing another trampoline in the yard absolutely odious.
List2.Friends Example: Janice’s laugh was so odious to Chandler that he broke up with her multiple times.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily found Lorelai’s lack of etiquette absolutely odious.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon found Howard’s loud chewing odious.

List2.Meaning: impenetrable by light; not reflecting light
List2.Modern Family Example: The logic behind Luke’s science project was so opaque that even Alex gave up trying to understand it.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel’s explanation for quitting her job was opaque at best—Monica suspected there was more to it.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The reason behind Emily’s sudden visit was opaque to Lorelai until she opened her purse.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy found Sheldon’s explanation of his emotions completely opaque.

List2.Modern Family Example: The oscillation of Cam’s mood swings confused Mitchell on their anniversary dinner.
List2.Friends Example: The oscillation of emotions between Ross and Rachel exhausted everyone around them.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s mood oscillation before exams drove Lorelai to hide the coffee.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: The oscillation of Penny’s relationship with Leonard gave everyone whiplash.

List2.Modern Family Example: Jay accused Phil of being penurious when he reused wrapping paper from last year.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s penurious lifestyle meant he reused coffee filters… until they were translucent.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai joked about her penurious teenage years while eating Pop-Tarts for dinner.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon accused Leonard of being penurious for buying generic cereal.

List2.Modern Family Example: Claire believed Gloria’s fashion advice was pernicious to her teenage daughters’ wardrobes.
List2.Friends Example: Ross warned Rachel about the pernicious effects of ignoring humidity on her hair in Barbados.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily warned that Lorelai’s rebellious ways were pernicious to the family name.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy claimed Sheldon’s sarcasm was pernicious to her self-esteem.

List2.Meaning: to examine with great care (noun form: perusal)
List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell sat on the porch to peruse Cam’s over-the-top event brochure with growing concern.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel stayed up late to peruse fashion magazines before her big job interview.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory would peruse three newspapers before breakfast.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon needed exactly 42 minutes to peruse his comic stack each Saturday.

List2.Meaning: extremely reverent or devout; showing strong religious devotion (noun form: piety)
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam’s pious devotion to holiday decorations made even the neighbors feel underprepared.
List2.Friends Example: Phoebe’s pious belief in karma shaped every romantic decision she made.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory gave a pious defense of classic literature in every class discussion.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s pious devotion to neuroscience rivaled Sheldon’s dedication to physics.

List2.Meaning: one that precedes and indicates or announces another
List2.Modern Family Example: Jay saw Luke’s sudden interest in tools as a precursor to his becoming a handyman.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s role in the soup commercial was a precursor to his 'Days of Our Lives' debut.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The faint smell of burnt pie was a precursor to Lorelai’s latest kitchen disaster.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s drone obsession was a precursor to his failed delivery startup idea.

List2.Meaning: to dress up; to primp; to groom oneself with elaborate care
List2.Modern Family Example: Haley took an hour to preen before her high school reunion.
List2.Friends Example: Joey loved to preen in front of the mirror before auditions.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai would preen before dates while sipping coffee in her robe.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard took longer to preen for a date than most supermodels.

List2.Meaning: | abundant in size, force, or extent; extraordinary
List2.Modern Family Example: Cam’s prodigious talent for musical theater turned even PTA meetings into showstoppers.
List2.Friends Example: Monica’s prodigious ability to clean impressed even the janitor of her building.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory had a prodigious reading list before age 10.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s prodigious memory allowed him to recite Pi to 1,000 digits.

List2.Meaning: producing large volumes or amounts; productive
List2.Modern Family Example: Alex became a prolific writer of science articles for her school’s newsletter.
List2.Friends Example: Ross was a prolific note-taker—each lecture had footnotes, citations, and illustrations.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was a prolific essay writer with multiple drafts per paper.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was a prolific writer of academic papers—on obscure physics topics.

List2.Meaning: to rot; to decay and give off a foul odor (adj. form: putrid)
List2.Modern Family Example: Phil forgot to take out the trash, and the garage began to putrefy in the summer heat.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s forgotten sandwich began to putrefy under his bed... discovered a week later.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The fridge at Yale began to putrefy after a week-long blackout.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard forgot lab leftovers in his locker until they began to putrefy.

List2.Modern Family Example: Jay watched in disbelief as Phil quaffed an entire protein shake in one gulp.
List2.Friends Example: Joey quaffed his orange juice like he hadn’t had a drink in days.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai could quaff three cups of coffee before 8 a.m.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny could quaff wine like a champ on bad date nights.

List2.Meaning: stillness; motionlessness; quality of being at rest (adj. form: quiescent) :
List2.Modern Family Example: There was a rare moment of quiescence in the Dunphy house after everyone went to sleep early.
List2.Friends Example: Central Perk experienced a moment of quiescence before Phoebe walked in with her guitar.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Stars Hollow had a strange moment of quiescence during a snowstorm.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon required total quiescence during his REM sleep cycle.

List2.Meaning: | awe-inspiring; worthy of honor; invincible and deserving respect
List2.Modern Family Example: Gloria was known as a redoubtable force at the PTA—no one dared oppose her event plans.
List2.Friends Example: Monica was a redoubtable chef—every Thanksgiving was a culinary battlefield she dominated.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily Gilmore was a redoubtable presence in any room.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Beverly Hofstadter was a redoubtable intellect that even Sheldon feared.

List2.Meaning: sordid; wretched and dirty as from neglect (noun form: squalor)
List2.Modern Family Example: Jay refused to stay in a squalid motel during their road trip, insisting on five-star only.
List2.Friends Example: Joey’s apartment became squalid after Chandler moved out—pizza boxes were the new wallpaper.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: The girls’ apartment got so squalid during finals that Lane wore gloves indoors.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s room turned squalid after he stopped cleaning post-breakup.

List2.Meaning: indifferent to or unaffected by pleasure or pain; steadfast
List2.Modern Family Example: Jay remained stoic even when the family vacation went completely off the rails.
List2.Friends Example: Ross tried to remain stoic when he saw Rachel on a date, but his eyes betrayed him.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily remained stoic during Lorelai’s rebellious rants, sipping tea in silence.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon stayed stoic even when his spot on the couch was taken—until he exploded two minutes later.

List2.Meaning: to take the place of; supersede
List2.Modern Family Example: Claire feared that Haley’s new boyfriend might supplant her influence.
List2.Friends Example: Emily tried to supplant Rachel in Ross’s life—but history had other plans.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris tried to supplant Rory as valedictorian with obsessive academic rigor.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy feared Penny might supplant her as Sheldon’s best friend after a girls’ night out.

List2.Modern Family Example: After a long PTA meeting, Cam felt torpid and barely made it to the couch.
List2.Friends Example: Joey was torpid all weekend after eating an entire turkey alone.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was torpid after a sleepless night managing the inn and dodging Emily’s calls.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj was torpid after staying up all night coding and eating leftover curry.

List2.Meaning: existing everywhere at the same time; widespread
List2.Modern Family Example: Phil’s cheesy jokes were so ubiquitous that even the kids used them.
List2.Friends Example: Gunther’s presence at Central Perk felt ubiquitous—he was always there, silently judging.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s wit and coffee addiction were ubiquitous in Stars Hollow.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s obsessive routines became ubiquitous across the apartment.

List2.Modern Family Example: Mitchell was known for his urbane style, always sharply dressed for every occasion.
List2.Friends Example: Chandler attempted to appear urbane at Monica’s work party but spilled wine on himself.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s urbane manner impressed everyone at the Yale alumni mixer.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard tried to act urbane during his physics conference speech but tripped over the podium.

List2.Meaning: to defame; to characterize harshly; slander
List2.Modern Family Example: Gloria felt vilified after her parenting choices were criticized in a blog post.
List2.Friends Example: Rachel felt vilified when her coworkers blamed her for the lost shipment.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai felt vilified after the town meeting twisted her joke into gossip.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon vilified Wil Wheaton for years over a trivia betrayal.

List2.Modern Family Example: Phil spilled syrup and tried to clean the viscous mess with a paper towel—bad idea.
List2.Friends Example: Joey struggled to clean the viscous cheese off the counter after his midnight snack.
List2.Gilmore Girls Example: Sookie spilled a viscous caramel sauce all over the kitchen and slipped in it.
List2.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard dropped a viscous chemical on the lab floor and blamed gravity.

List3.Meaning: keen, accurate judgment or insight; discernment; perspicacity
List3.Modern Family Example: Alex’s business acumen helped her dominate the student market fair.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s fashion acumen earned her a promotion at work.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s journalistic acumen impressed the Yale Daily News editor.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s acumen in neuroscience impressed even Sheldon.

List3.Meaning: to reduce purity by combining with inferior ingredients
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil accidentally adulterated the lemonade with vinegar during a party.
List3.Friends Example: Joey adulterated the soup by adding everything in the fridge.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai accused the chef of adulterating the soup with instant noodles.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard accidentally adulterated the rocket fuel mixture.

List3.Meaning: to combine several elements into a whole
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam and Mitchell tried to amalgamate their holiday traditions—with chaotic results.
List3.Friends Example: Monica tried to amalgamate multiple cuisines into one Thanksgiving meal.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Sookie tried to amalgamate six different dessert recipes into one pie.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon tried to amalgamate theories of relativity and quantum mechanics.

List3.Meaning: outdated; associated with an earlier, perhaps more primitive, time
List3.Modern Family Example: Jay’s archaic views on parenting clashed with Gloria’s modern approach.
List3.Friends Example: Ross’s archaic language made even the museum interns snicker.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s archaic dinner traditions clashed with Lorelai’s laid-back attitude.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s archaic computer baffled even the tech support rep.

List3.Meaning: to state as a fact; to declare or assert
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire averted disaster by averring that the accident was not Luke’s fault.
List3.Friends Example: Monica averred that she did not break the lamp—even though she obviously did.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory averred that she was capable of handling Yale and Logan.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon averred that he was the rightful owner of the spot.

List3.Meaning: to provide support or reinforcement
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil tried to bolster his argument with graphs and cheesy slogans.
List3.Friends Example: Ross tried to bolster his dinosaur facts with exaggerated hand gestures.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai bolstered Rory’s confidence before every big interview.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard bolstered Penny’s confidence before her presentation.

List3.Meaning: pompous; grandiloquent
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s bombastic speech at the PTA made even Mitchell roll his eyes.
List3.Friends Example: Joey gave a bombastic acceptance speech for a non-existent award.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s bombastic introduction at the debate had the moderator stunned.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s bombastic speech about space made Raj tear up.

List3.Meaning: a harsh denunciation; tirade
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire launched into a diatribe when she discovered the kids broke the Wi-Fi router.
List3.Friends Example: Ross launched into a diatribe about marriage during a coffee break.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily went on a diatribe when the caterer brought the wrong floral centerpiece.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s diatribe against geology scared the undergrads.

List3.Meaning: to disguise or conceal; to mislead
List3.Modern Family Example: Lily tried to dissemble her guilt after breaking Cam’s prized vase.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe tried to dissemble her real feelings about Mike’s new girlfriend.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai dissembled her nerves with jokes at Sookie’s wedding.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj dissembled his nervousness behind awkward flattery.

List3.Meaning: departing from norms or conventions
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke’s eccentric inventions usually resulted in backyard explosions.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s eccentric behavior was just her version of normal.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s eccentric business ventures confused half of Stars Hollow.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s eccentric routines baffled Penny every time.

List3.Meaning: characteristic of or often found in a particular locality, region, or people
List3.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s accent and sayings were endemic to her Colombian roots.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s pizza obsession seemed endemic to all his New York adventures.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Miss Patty’s tales were endemic to Stars Hollow lore.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Comic book debates were endemic to their Friday nights.

List3.Meaning: tending to disappear like vapor; transient
List3.Modern Family Example: The evanescent joy from Lily’s birthday party faded once the cleanup began.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s excitement over her date was evanescent after he called her ‘Monica.’
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s fleeting interest in basket weaving was evanescent as usual.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s crushes were evanescent, changing weekly.

List3.Meaning: to make worse or more severe
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell’s criticism only exacerbated Cam’s post-rehearsal meltdown.
List3.Friends Example: Chandler’s joke exacerbated Monica’s already bad day.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s sharp tone exacerbated an already tense Friday night dinner.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s comments only exacerbated Penny’s acting stress.

List3.Meaning: greatly emotional or zealous
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s fervent love for drama was apparent at every school play.
List3.Friends Example: Ross had a fervent passion for paleontology—and correcting grammar.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s fervent defense of her paper left everyone speechless.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s fervent monologue on brain scans left everyone speechless.

List3.Meaning: happening by accident or chance
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s fortuitous meeting with a client at the dog park landed him a big deal.
List3.Friends Example: Joey got a fortuitous acting role after a guy no-showed to the audition.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s fortuitous run-in with an editor led to an internship.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s fortuitous tweet landed him a speaking engagement.

List3.Meaning: relevant to the subject at hand
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire’s question about curfews was perfectly germane during the family debate.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s remark about turkey timing was germane to Monica’s panic.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s remark about zoning was surprisingly germane to the town hall drama.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s point about string theory was surprisingly germane to the conversation.

List3.Meaning: pompous speech or expression
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s grandiloquence during a toast made everyone wish he kept it shorter.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s grandiloquence in her songs confused most listeners.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s grandiloquence at every festival opening was exhausting.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s grandiloquence during award ceremonies made Amy cringe.

List3.Meaning: rendered trite or commonplace by frequent usage
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s Halloween ideas were so hackneyed that Mitchell banned them entirely.
List3.Friends Example: Monica’s holiday speeches had become so hackneyed the group recited them with her.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s compliments became hackneyed over the years—always about posture.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s hackneyed pickup lines failed at every bar.

List3.Meaning: calm and peaceful
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire longed for the halcyon days before teenagers and sarcasm.
List3.Friends Example: Chandler missed the halcyon days of bachelor life after diaper duty.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai longed for halcyon days when coffee solved everything.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s halcyon moment involved labeling all his storage boxes.

List3.Meaning: devotion to pleasurable pursuits
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s hedonism peaked at the all-you-can-eat pancake contest.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s hedonism was evident in his two-pizza, no-sharing lifestyle.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Michel’s hedonism peaked with his weekly spa routine.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s hedonism was evident at the chocolate tasting.

List3.Meaning: the consistent dominance of one state or ideology over others
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire maintained hegemony over the household schedules with military precision.
List3.Friends Example: Monica held hegemony over Thanksgiving menus year after year.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s hegemony over town events remained unchallenged until Kirk intervened.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon claimed hegemony over roommate agreements.

List3.Meaning: one who attacks or undermines traditional conventions or institutions
List3.Modern Family Example: Alex was an iconoclast at school, challenging every club rule.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe was the iconoclast of the group, always challenging traditions.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory played iconoclast during her Chilton speech, rejecting social norms.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy was the iconoclast of neuroscience conferences with her novel theories.

List3.Meaning: given to intense or excessive devotion to something
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s idolatrous admiration for Barbra Streisand was unmatched.
List3.Friends Example: Ross’s idolatrous love for dinosaurs bordered on obsessive.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s idolatrous love for coffee was practically religious.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s idolatrous obsession with Spock unnerved even Leonard.

List3.Meaning: revealing no emotion
List3.Modern Family Example: Jay stayed impassive during Lily’s chaotic birthday puppet show.
List3.Friends Example: Chandler remained impassive during Joey’s dramatic breakup stories.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke remained impassive while Taylor ranted about sign placements.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon remained impassive as Howard mocked his shirts.

List3.Meaning: marked by extreme calm and steadiness
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell was imperturbable—even when Cam spilled juice on his suit.
List3.Friends Example: Ross was imperturbable while explaining fossils—even during coffee spills.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s imperturbable cool cracked only when Rory’s grades dropped.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s imperturbable smile hid her true sarcasm.

List3.Meaning: not capable of being appeased or significantly changed
