List3.Modern Family Example: Claire was implacable after discovering someone dented her new car.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel was implacable after Ross ruined her prom video moment.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was implacable after losing her top ranking at Yale.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny was implacable after Leonard spoiled her show finale.

List3.Meaning: immunity from punishment or penalty
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke seemed to operate with impunity after learning how to erase browser history.
List3.Friends Example: Joey acted with impunity in Monica’s kitchen, ignoring all her labels.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk often behaved with impunity due to town-wide tolerance.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard thought he had impunity when he ‘borrowed’ lab supplies.

List3.Meaning: in an initial stage; not fully formed
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s business idea was still inchoate, mostly just a doodle and a jingle.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s business pitch was still inchoate, mostly just magazine clippings.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s novel outline remained inchoate through the semester.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s robot project was still inchoate by competition day.

List3.Meaning: unfortunate; inappropriate
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s infelicitous joke at the wedding nearly caused a family feud.
List3.Friends Example: Chandler’s infelicitous toast at the wedding made everyone cringe.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s infelicitous joke about Emily’s hat caused another silent treatment.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s infelicitous joke at the party got total silence.

List3.Meaning: without taste or flavor; lacking in spirit
List3.Modern Family Example: Lily’s reaction to her birthday gift was insipid—just a polite smile.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s acting notes were insipid—mostly doodles and hearts.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s insipid date left her longing for book club.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s soup tasted insipid, despite Penny’s fake praise.

List3.Meaning: extremely talkative
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell regretted asking a loquacious Cam how rehearsal went.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe was so loquacious that even the parrot gave up.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Babette was loquacious—even her cat seemed exhausted.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard became loquacious when talking about zero gravity toilets.

List3.Meaning: characterized by brightness and light
List3.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s luminous smile lit up every family photo.
List3.Friends Example: Monica’s ring sparkled with a luminous gleam in the coffeehouse lights.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s smile was luminous under the graduation lights.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: The luminous lights of Sheldon’s lab impressed Amy.

List3.Meaning: having or showing ill will; spiteful; malicious
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire suspected malevolent intent when Luke offered to do chores unprompted.
List3.Friends Example: Ross’s malevolent dinosaur prank gave Chandler nightmares.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s malevolent tone implied punishment for Lorelai’s lateness.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s malevolent glare scared off Wil Wheaton—temporarily.

List3.Meaning: capable of being shaped or formed; tractable; pliable
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil was malleable enough to change his Halloween costume three times for Claire.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s malleable schedule let him audition on zero notice.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s malleable schedule let her juggle Yale and the Gazette.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s malleable schedule revolved around his spot on the couch.

List3.Meaning: the condition of being untruthful; dishonesty

List3.Friends Example: Chandler called out Ross’s mendacity when he fibbed about the leather pants.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai saw through Emily’s polite mendacity about the inn décor.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard accused Sheldon of mendacity over the roommate agreement.

List3.Meaning: characterized by extreme care and precision; attentive to detail
List3.Modern Family Example: Alex’s meticulous science fair project included footnotes and a bibliography.
List3.Friends Example: Monica’s meticulous towel folding was famous—and terrifying.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s meticulous notes scared even her professors.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s meticulous lab techniques impressed the university dean.

List3.Meaning: one who hates all other humans
List3.Modern Family Example: Jay called himself a misanthrope after spending a day with too many neighbors.
List3.Friends Example: Ross joked that he became a misanthrope every Thanksgiving with his parents.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke jokingly called Kirk a misanthrope after he chased off tourists.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon claimed he was a proud misanthrope, especially at Comic-Con.

List3.Meaning: to make or become less severe or intense; to moderate; mollify
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell tried to mitigate Cam’s anxiety with a dramatic spa day plan.
List3.Friends Example: Monica tried to mitigate the awkwardness after bringing up Janice at dinner.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai tried to mitigate tension with coffee and jokes.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny tried to mitigate the fallout from missing Sheldon’s lecture.

List3.Meaning: unyielding; hardhearted; intractable
List3.Modern Family Example: Gloria was obdurate about not letting Manny drop out of fencing class.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel was obdurate about not calling Ross—even after seeing the prom video.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily was obdurate about keeping Friday dinners formal.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon remained obdurate about his bathroom schedule.

List3.Meaning: exhibiting a fawning attentiveness; subservient
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam’s obsequious behavior around the new principal made Mitchell cringe.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s obsequious charm got him free muffins from the waitress.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was obsequious around her literature professor to earn favor.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj became obsequious around celebrities, fawning relentlessly.

List3.Meaning: to obstruct or block
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke accidentally occluded the sink with an ill-placed science experiment.
List3.Friends Example: Ross occluded the hallway with dinosaur boxes—again.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s faulty wiring occluded the Stars Hollow sign again.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard occluded the whiteboard with his comic sketches.

List3.Meaning: disgrace; contempt; scorn
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s magic show ended in opprobrium when he spilled juice on the mayor.
List3.Friends Example: Joey faced opprobrium after forgetting his lines on live television.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai faced opprobrium after skipping out on her engagement party.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon faced opprobrium after insulting geology at a conference.

List3.Meaning: the profession or principles of teaching or instructing
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire believed in strong pedagogy—even during family game night quizzes.
List3.Friends Example: Ross loved pedagogy so much he turned every date into a lecture.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was fascinated by pedagogy and insisted on extra lectures.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon discussed pedagogy in minute detail for his guest lecture.

List3.Meaning: the parading of learning; showing off one’s knowledge
List3.Modern Family Example: Alex’s pedantic tone during dinner made everyone lose their appetite.
List3.Friends Example: Ross’s pedantic obsession with grammar annoyed everyone.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s pedantic style made her Yale roommates hide during discussions.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s pedantic rants made even Leonard roll his eyes.

List3.Meaning: poverty; destitution
List3.Modern Family Example: Lily’s lemonade stand failed due to penury—Cam forgot the lemons.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe joked about living in penury after her cab broke down again.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai joked about her penury while paying for wedding flowers.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s spending sprees were followed by weekends of penury.

List3.Meaning: having the tendency to permeate or spread throughout

List3.Friends Example: Chandler’s sarcastic tone became pervasive in every serious talk.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s ambition was pervasive—even in her casual conversations.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s voice became a pervasive background sound in every room.

List3.Meaning: to yearn intensely; to languish; to lose vigor

List3.Friends Example: Rachel began to pine for Paris after reading travel brochures.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lane began to pine for band practice while working double shifts.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy began to pine for a date night after weeks in the lab.

List3.Meaning: to illegally use or reproduce

List3.Friends Example: Joey pirated his audition tape using Monica’s VCR.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory pirated books when she couldn’t afford the required editions.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard pirated a movie—then complained about the quality nonstop.

List3.Meaning: the essential or central part

List3.Friends Example: Chandler quickly cut to the pith of the conversation: ‘You’re moving?!’
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai always got to the pith of a problem with humor and coffee.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon got to the pith of the roommate issue with a flowchart.

List3.Meaning: precise and brief; terse; to-the-point; laconic

List3.Friends Example: Monica gave a pithy review: ‘No. Just no.’
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s pithy critiques reduced class essays to shreds.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s pithy summary of neurobiology stunned the board.

List3.Meaning: to appease; to calm by making concessions

List3.Friends Example: Phoebe placated Rachel with a cookie after a fight.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory placated Emily with a perfectly polite thank-you note.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny placated Sheldon with cookies after forgetting laundry night.

List3.Meaning: a superficial remark; common comment; dull and boring

List3.Friends Example: Ross’s toast was full of platitudes no one remembered.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s speeches were full of platitudes and floral metaphors.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s speech was full of wedding platitudes.

List3.Meaning: to plunge or drop straight down; fall steeply

List3.Friends Example: Chandler’s confidence plummeted after seeing Monica’s ex.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s GPA plummeted after too many extracurriculars.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s confidence plummeted during the failed proposal.

List3.Meaning: controversial; argumentative

List3.Friends Example: Dinner with the group turned polemical when they debated cats vs. dogs.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Debates with Paris turned polemical in seconds.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s Facebook rants turned polemical fast.

List3.Meaning: recklessly wasteful; extravagant; lavish
List3.Modern Family Example: Haley’s prodigal use of the credit card got her grounded for a month.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s prodigal shopping sprees worried her bank account.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was prodigal with coffee money during finals season.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard was prodigal with gadgets he barely used.

List3.Meaning: given or coming forth abundantly; extravagant

List3.Friends Example: Joey gave profuse thanks to every girl—often at once.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Babette gave profuse hugs after Rory’s graduation.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny gave profuse compliments to avoid awkward silence.

List3.Meaning: to grow or increase swiftly and abundantly; multiply rapidly

List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s song lyrics seemed to proliferate with each break-up.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Flyers for town events proliferated across Stars Hollow overnight.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Memes of Sheldon’s quirks proliferated across Reddit.

List3.Meaning: prone to complaining or grumbling; peevish
List3.Modern Family Example: Lily was querulous after being denied her third scoop of ice cream.
List3.Friends Example: Ross grew querulous after being corrected one too many times.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s querulous complaints about dorm food never stopped.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was querulous after someone adjusted his thermostat.

List3.Meaning: characterized by bitter, long-lasting resentment
List3.Modern Family Example: Jay’s rancorous tone about his ex-wife made Thanksgiving awkward.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel had a rancorous reaction to seeing Ross with Julie.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s rancorous remarks about Lorelai’s lifestyle stung deeply.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s rancorous breakup texts shocked even Howard.

List3.Meaning: obstinately defiant of authority; difficult to manage
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke’s recalcitrant behavior got him banned from using the drone.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s recalcitrant attitude made wedding planning a challenge.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s recalcitrant attitude surfaced when asked about Logan.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was recalcitrant about changing his bathroom routine.

List3.Meaning: to refuse to have anything to do with; disown
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell chose to repudiate Cam’s suggestion of matching tracksuits.
List3.Friends Example: Monica repudiated the idea of ‘casual cleaning.’
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai repudiated the idea of being like her mother.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard repudiated Sheldon’s backup plans in a rare moment of rebellion.

List3.Meaning: to invalidate; to repeal
List3.Modern Family Example: Gloria had to rescind her RSVP after realizing it clashed with salsa night.
List3.Friends Example: Chandler tried to rescind his bet with Joey after realizing the stakes.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily had to rescind her charity invite after a scandal.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard had to rescind a launch comment that offended NASA.

List3.Meaning: marked by or expressing profound awe and respect
List3.Modern Family Example: Lily gave a reverent look to her doll before tucking it into bed.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel looked reverent while holding her newborn for the first time.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s reverent gaze lingered on Richard’s old books.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy gave Sheldon a reverent look after his Nobel speech.

List3.Meaning: the art of effective language use for communication or persuasion
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil gave a whole speech on rhetorical techniques during breakfast.
List3.Friends Example: Ross gave an impromptu lecture on dinosaur rhetoric during brunch.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s dinner speeches were full of exaggerated rhetoric.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon gave a lecture on rhetoric—no one asked for it.

List3.Meaning: promoting health or well-being
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam promoted his new low-fat cupcakes as salubrious—even if no one liked them.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s herbal tea was salubrious—but awful.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s diner food may not be salubrious—but it was comforting.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s smoothies weren’t salubrious—but they had umbrellas.

List3.Meaning: able to meet financial obligations; able to dissolve another substance
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire reminded Haley to stay solvent if she wanted to move out.
List3.Friends Example: Monica insisted everyone pay their share to stay solvent.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily doubted Lorelai’s ability to stay solvent with inn bills piling.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard doubted his ability to remain solvent post-fatherhood.

List3.Meaning: seeming true, but actually being fallacious; misleadingly attractive
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s pitch was specious—sounded great but lacked substance.
List3.Friends Example: Joey’s explanation for the broken fridge was specious at best.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s specious argument about studying was uncovered quickly.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s explanation for the missed call was oddly specious.

List3.Meaning: lacking authenticity or validity; false; counterfeit
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke’s story about the ‘ghost raccoon’ turned out to be completely spurious.
List3.Friends Example: The story Joey told about his twin was hilariously spurious.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s spurious business ideas were hilariously persistent.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard dismissed the spurious science claims on TV with a sigh.

List3.Meaning: a court order requiring appearance and/or testimony
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam was shocked when he received a subpoena to testify at the school board meeting.
List3.Friends Example: Joey didn’t realize he needed to respond to a subpoena until Chandler explained it wasn’t a pizza.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai panicked when she got a subpoena for a business licensing issue.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon took the subpoena as an opportunity to lecture in court.

List3.Meaning: brief; concise
List3.Modern Family Example: Alex gave a succinct summary of the family drama in under 10 seconds.
List3.Friends Example: Monica’s instructions for cleaning were anything but succinct.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory gave a succinct report during her Yale editorial meeting.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s explanation of neurobiology was always succinct—and intimidating.

List3.Meaning: exceeding what is sufficient or necessary
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s superfluous explanations made the simple house tour unnecessarily long.
List3.Friends Example: Ross’s explanation of dinosaurs included superfluous facts no one asked for.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s superfluous flower arrangements filled every inch of the banquet hall.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s PowerPoints were filled with superfluous footnotes and trivia.

List3.Meaning: an overabundant supply; excess; to feed or supply to excess
List3.Modern Family Example: Gloria served a surfeit of empanadas, which left even Jay stuffed for hours.
List3.Friends Example: Joey had a surfeit of sandwiches after confusing catering with hoarding.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk delivered a surfeit of brochures to every home in Stars Hollow.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard brought a surfeit of snacks to space training and didn’t share.

List3.Meaning: persistent determination; adherence to something valued
List3.Modern Family Example: Claire’s tenacity during election season won her both admiration and exhaustion.
List3.Friends Example: Monica’s tenacity in organizing Thanksgiving was both terrifying and impressive.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s tenacity at Chilton helped her rise to the top despite Paris’s rivalry.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s tenacity with physics equations was both impressive and annoying.

List3.Meaning: having little substance or strength; flimsy; weak
List3.Modern Family Example: Luke’s tenuous excuse for missing class barely held up under Claire’s questioning.
List3.Friends Example: Phoebe’s tenuous claim that her cab had magical powers made everyone raise eyebrows.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s tenuous excuse for being late unraveled under Emily’s glare.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s tenuous claim to ‘date’ status fell apart quickly under questioning.

List3.Meaning: a long and extremely critical speech; a harsh denunciation
List3.Modern Family Example: Mitchell launched into a tirade when the city denied their building permit again.
List3.Friends Example: Ross delivered a tirade about evolution at Thanksgiving—again.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily launched into a tirade when the wine was served too warm.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard endured Sheldon’s tirade after rearranging the action figures.

List3.Meaning: fleeting; passing quickly; brief
List3.Modern Family Example: Phil’s enthusiasm for his new invention was transient—it faded after one use.
List3.Friends Example: Rachel’s interest in her new job was transient—until a cuter co-worker arrived.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s interest in yoga was transient—she quit after one session.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s interest in string theory was transient—it lasted 5 minutes.

List3.Meaning: fervent; ardent; impassioned; devoted to a cause
List3.Modern Family Example: Cam was zealous about directing the school musical, even designing all the costumes himself.
List3.Friends Example: Ross was zealous about his lecture series, complete with trivia and fossil giveaways.
List3.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was zealous about dominating every debate and academic contest.
List3.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was zealous about enforcing the roommate agreement—even on holidays.

List4.Meaning: having a sour or bitter taste or character; sharp; biting; caustic
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire’s acerbic response to Phil’s magic tricks shut down the show instantly.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler’s acerbic wit turned every awkward moment into an iconic joke.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s acerbic comments during class made even professors pause.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s acerbic response to Penny’s movie choice was immediate.

List4.Meaning: to increase in intensity, power, influence, or prestige
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam tried to aggrandize his role in the school play, despite only directing one scene.
List4.Friends Example: Joey tried to aggrandize his part in the movie—he was ‘the silent hero.’
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily tried to aggrandize her role in Rory’s college decision process.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard tried to aggrandize his space mission every chance he got.

List4.Meaning: a medieval science aimed at the transmutation of metals, esp. base metals into gold
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil treated real estate negotiations like alchemy—mixing charm with chaos.
List4.Friends Example: Ross explained alchemy to everyone... again... in great unnecessary detail.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai joked that Luke’s coffee was strong enough for alchemy.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon said science was real—alchemy was nonsense.

List4.Meaning: agreeable; responsive to suggestion
List4.Modern Family Example: Mitchell was more amenable to brunch plans once he saw mimosas on the menu.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel was amenable to the blind date until she saw who it was.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was amenable to changing her major—after three cups of coffee.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy was amenable to trying Sheldon’s gaming night... once.

List4.Meaning: something or someone out of place in terms of historical or chronological context
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay’s flip phone was a hilarious anachronism at the tech convention.
List4.Friends Example: Joey’s pager was an embarrassing anachronism in the modern office.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s Walkman was an anachronism in a sea of smartphones at Yale.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s MySpace account was a digital anachronism.

List4.Meaning: having a tightening effect on living tissue; harsh; severe
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s astringent tone scared the kids into doing their homework immediately.
List4.Friends Example: Monica used an astringent face mask so strong it nearly paralyzed her smile.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s astringent remarks about Lorelai’s clothes left no survivors.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s astringent commentary made Leonard rethink dinner topics.

List4.Meaning: self-important or pompous writing or speech
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam’s bombast during the charity auction made Mitchell hide behind a plant.
List4.Friends Example: Ross’s bombast about his PhD made even Phoebe doze off.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s bombast at town meetings became a running gag.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s bombast about engineering made Sheldon roll his eyes.

List4.Meaning: sharing a border; touching; adjacent
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s property line was contiguous with a goat farm—his nightmares were real.
List4.Friends Example: Monica’s apartment was contiguous with Joey’s—dangerous for fridge raids.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s inn was contiguous with a noisy neighbor, much to her dismay.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon refused to live contiguous to anyone with loud music.

List4.Meaning: a generally agreed-upon practice or attitude
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire insisted on following every parenting convention in the book.
List4.Friends Example: Thanksgiving dinner followed the exact convention—until Chandler ruined it.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Friday night dinners followed convention—until Rory brought Logan.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: The roommate agreement was based on strict convention.

List4.Meaning: tending to believe too readily; gullible
List4.Modern Family Example: Luke was so credulous, he believed Phil’s story about invisible burglars.
List4.Friends Example: Joey was so credulous, he believed soap operas were documentaries.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was credulous enough to believe Jess had changed—for a moment.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj was so credulous, he believed every dating app review.

List4.Meaning: an attitude or quality of belief that all people are motivated by selfishness
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay’s cynicism about family bonding faded after Lily’s heartfelt drawing.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe’s cynicism about marriage shocked even Ross.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s cynicism grew with each town festival he had to sponsor.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s cynicism emerged every time his mother visited.

List4.Meaning: polite or appropriate conduct or behavior
List4.Modern Family Example: Mitchell tried to maintain decorum while Cam sang show tunes in court.
List4.Friends Example: Monica demanded decorum at dinner—no burping allowed.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory tried to maintain decorum during the alumni mixer.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy maintained decorum during Sheldon’s Nobel lecture.

List4.Meaning: scorn; ridicule; contemptuous treatment
List4.Modern Family Example: Lily’s prank drew derision from the entire school when it backfired.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel’s fashion advice was met with derision from Janice.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s costume drew derision at the Star’s Hollow dance.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s singing earned derision at karaoke night.

List4.Meaning: to dry out or dehydrate; to make dry or dull
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam’s soufflé desiccated after Jay opened the oven too soon.
List4.Friends Example: Ross’s enthusiasm for fossils desiccated the group’s attention span.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s enthusiasm desiccated by the third town meeting of the day.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s enthusiasm for string theory desiccated when Amy outshone him.

List4.Meaning: one with an amateurish or superficial interest in the arts or a branch of knowledge
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil became a dilettante in photography—buying gear but never using it.
List4.Friends Example: Joey was a true dilettante—guitar one week, origami the next.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk became a dilettante in landscaping—half-finished projects everywhere.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj was a dilettante in hobbies—one week astronomy, next week dog yoga.

List4.Meaning: to slight or belittle; to play down
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire disparaged Phil’s app idea, calling it ‘Uber but worse.’
List4.Friends Example: Monica disparaged Chandler’s tie—then fixed it before he left.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris disparaged everyone’s paper before offering unsolicited rewrites.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon disparaged Wolowitz’s Master’s degree at every opportunity.

List4.Meaning: to disclose something secret
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria accidentally divulged Mitchell’s job interview plans during brunch.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler accidentally divulged Ross’s crush at the worst possible moment.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily accidentally divulged Lorelai’s engagement over brunch.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny accidentally divulged Leonard’s proposal plans to everyone.

List4.Meaning: to flatter or praise excessively; grovel
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam would fawn over talent show judges even if Lily forgot her lines.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel would fawn over her boss to avoid getting fired.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Michel would fawn over every food critic like his job depended on it.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard would fawn over astronauts—even the ones who ignored him.

List4.Meaning: to show contempt for, as in a rule or convention; violate
List4.Modern Family Example: Luke flouted the house rules by building a treehouse with fireworks.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe flouted logic every time she explained her past lives.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai flouted traditional business rules with every quirky inn decision.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon flouted fire drill protocol to finish a physics experiment.

List4.Meaning: pointlessly talkative, talking too much; loquacious
List4.Modern Family Example: Mitchell found Cam’s garrulous wedding stories charming but exhausting.
List4.Friends Example: Joey’s garrulous audition made the director say, ‘Cut!’ ten times.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Babette’s garrulous nature made a five-minute update last an hour.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s garrulous monologue about his ex bored the entire group.

List4.Meaning: marked by ease or informality; nonchalant; lacking in depth; superficial
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s glib pitch about ‘Cloud Castles’ left the clients confused.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler’s glib remark about moving in nearly started a breakup.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s glib answer about her future worried Lorelai.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny’s glib answer to Sheldon’s question was ‘just because.’

List4.Meaning: overbearing presumption or pride; arrogance
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay’s hubris got the best of him when he challenged Gloria to a salsa duel.
List4.Friends Example: Ross’s hubris nearly ruined his second wedding, too.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Logan’s hubris often clashed with Rory’s ambition.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s hubris led to his downfall in trivia night—twice.

List4.Meaning: about to happen; impending
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire warned that if they didn’t hurry, Gloria’s rage would be imminent.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe shouted that labor was imminent—and everyone panicked.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris declared the apocalypse was imminent—due to a late paper.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy warned that if they skipped their lab deadline, disaster was imminent.

List4.Meaning: not capable of change
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay believed some traditions were immutable—like Sunday grilling.
List4.Friends Example: Ross thought his museum routines were immutable—until they changed the label colors.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai believed some coffee habits were immutable.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon considered his seat preference immutable.

List4.Meaning: hastily or rashly energetic; impulsive and vehement
List4.Modern Family Example: Luke’s impetuous decision to skateboard off the roof ended predictably in chaos.
List4.Friends Example: Joey’s impetuous decision to buy a boat left him broke and confused.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s impetuous decision to follow Jess to New York shocked everyone.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s impetuous comment about Mars training landed him in trouble.

List4.Meaning: having no interest or concern; showing no bias or prejudice; nonchalant
List4.Modern Family Example: Alex showed indifferent disinterest when her cousins messed up her books.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel was indifferent to Ross’s dinosaur facts unless there was wine.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily was indifferent to Stars Hollow traditions—until one won her over.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny was indifferent to most scientific discussions.

List4.Meaning: damaging; harmful; injurious
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria saw Claire’s comments as inimical to her fashion sense.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler’s inimical remarks about Ross’s dates got him a glare.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor believed Lorelai’s inn renovations were inimical to town charm.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon believed incorrect data was deeply inimical to his psyche.

List4.Meaning: not easily managed or directed; stubborn; obstinate
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s intractable optimism couldn’t be dimmed—even during power outages.
List4.Friends Example: Monica’s intractable need to clean made living with her… exhausting.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris was intractable during debate prep, ignoring every suggestion.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s intractable obsession with routine drove Leonard mad.

List4.Meaning: steadfast and courageous; dauntless
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire was intrepid in confronting the raccoon in the garage—while Phil screamed.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe was intrepid in trying any new food—even if it glowed.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was intrepid during her first solo trip to New York.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy was intrepid at conferences, holding her own against Nobel laureates.

List4.Meaning: using few words; terse
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay’s laconic texts always read like business memos.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler’s laconic humor came in one-liners and smirks.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s laconic replies often meant more than whole conversations.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s laconic replies often followed a lengthy rant.

List4.Meaning: an independent individual who does not go along with a group or party
List4.Modern Family Example: Lily was a maverick in school—refusing to follow any lunchroom rules.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe was a maverick—refusing to sing anything remotely mainstream.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Jess was a maverick—skipping school and writing his own rules.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was a maverick even among theoretical physicists.

List4.Meaning: characterized by rapid and unpredictable change in mood
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam’s mood was so mercurial, Mitchell carried a ‘feelings meter.’
List4.Friends Example: Ross’s mercurial moods baffled everyone—especially during holidays.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s mercurial moods made Emily nervous about every conversation.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s mercurial dating moods confused even his dog.

List4.Meaning: to calm or soothe; to reduce in emotional intensity
List4.Modern Family Example: Mitchell tried to mollify Cam with brownies after forgetting their anniversary.
List4.Friends Example: Monica tried to mollify her parents with a perfect pie after forgetting their anniversary.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai tried to mollify Sookie with coffee after changing the menu last minute.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy mollified Sheldon with tea after Fun With Flags got canceled.

List4.Meaning: a recent convert; a beginner; novice
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil was a neophyte at parenting—learning diaper skills on the job.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel was a neophyte at waiting tables—and it showed.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was a neophyte at journalism, still learning the ropes.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny was a neophyte in quantum physics—but a fast learner.

List4.Meaning: to deliberately obscure; to make confusing
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam obfuscated the budget report with glitter and emojis.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler obfuscated his emotions with sarcasm.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor obfuscated the permit rules to delay Lorelai’s inn.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard obfuscated the real cost of his gadgets from Bernadette.

List4.Meaning: stubborn; hardheaded; uncompromising
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria was obstinate about keeping her leopard print wallpaper.
List4.Friends Example: Ross remained obstinate about his ‘we were on a break’ theory.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily was obstinate about dress codes at Friday dinners.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was obstinate about his spot on the couch.

List4.Meaning: characterized by or given to pretentious display; show
List4.Modern Family Example: Haley’s outfit at dinner was... ostentatious, even by her standards.
List4.Friends Example: Joey’s jacket was so ostentatious, it nearly blinded Chandler.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s party dress was nothing short of ostentatious.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s belt buckle collection was... ostentatious.

List4.Meaning: to permeate throughout
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s enthusiasm for real estate pervaded every family conversation.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe’s optimism pervaded the group—even during job crises.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s joy pervaded the entire inn on opening day.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s opinions pervaded every conversation—solicited or not.

List4.Meaning: calm; sluggish; unemotional
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay remained phlegmatic during even the noisiest family meltdowns.
List4.Friends Example: Ross was unusually phlegmatic about being dumped—until wine hit.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory stayed phlegmatic during Yale interviews—on the surface.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard stayed phlegmatic even when Sheldon insulted him.

List4.Meaning: an overabundance; a surplus; glut; scads
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire baked a plethora of cookies—then hid them from Luke.
List4.Friends Example: Monica prepared a plethora of Thanksgiving dishes… even duck confit.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai made a plethora of jokes to hide her anxiety.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard brought a plethora of snacks to every D&D game.

List4.Meaning: practical rather than idealistic
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire’s pragmatic approach to birthday parties included spreadsheets.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel’s pragmatic shopping strategy: sale + style = success.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke’s pragmatic advice helped Rory through college decisions.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s pragmatic solution was usually: 'Just lie to him.'

List4.Meaning: overstepping due bounds; taking liberties
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s presumptuous suggestion that he could ‘fix the dishwasher’ ended in disaster.
List4.Friends Example: Joey made a presumptuous move kissing Chandler’s new date.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Logan made a presumptuous entrance to Lorelai’s inn—without knocking.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s presumptuous romantic gestures rarely worked out.

List4.Meaning: pure; uncorrupted; clean; immaculate
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s garden was pristine—until Joe started digging.
List4.Friends Example: Monica kept her kitchen pristine—unless Joey visited.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: The Dragonfly Inn was pristine thanks to Michel’s obsessive cleaning.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy kept her lab pristine—no exceptions.

List4.Meaning: adherence to highest principles; complete integrity; uprightness
List4.Modern Family Example: Mitchell’s probity made him the perfect candidate for school legal advice.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe’s probity showed when she returned a found wallet full of cash.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s probity made her a favorite of professors.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s probity was unwavering, especially in contracts.

List4.Meaning: a natural predisposition or inclination
List4.Modern Family Example: Alex had a proclivity for academic competitions and spreadsheets.
List4.Friends Example: Ross had a proclivity for long lectures and shorter relationships.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Jess had a proclivity for brooding near bookshelves.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard had a proclivity for making bad jokes at NASA events.

List4.Meaning: excessively wasteful; recklessly extravagant
List4.Modern Family Example: Luke’s profligate spending on tech gadgets made Phil sweat.
List4.Friends Example: Joey’s profligate spending on cologne left him broke and pungent.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Logan’s profligate spending stunned even Lorelai.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s profligate spending on cologne had Penny worried.

List4.Meaning: a natural inclination or tendency; penchant
List4.Modern Family Example: Cam’s propensity to cry during musicals was legendary.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel had a propensity for dramatic exits from coffee shops.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory had a propensity to over-apologize—even when she wasn’t wrong.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Penny had a propensity for eavesdropping through the door.

List4.Meaning: dull; lacking in spirit or imagination
List4.Modern Family Example: Jay’s prosaic birthday card was redeemed by a heartfelt note.
List4.Friends Example: Chandler’s apartment décor was intentionally prosaic.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily’s prosaic tea parties contrasted with Lorelai’s vibrant style.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Leonard’s prosaic responses bored Penny during arguments.

List4.Meaning: characterized by a strong, sharp smell or taste
List4.Modern Family Example: Gloria’s kitchen had a pungent aroma from her spicy soup.
List4.Friends Example: Phoebe’s potpourri gave off a pungent smell that made Ross sneeze.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Babette’s chili had a pungent smell that filled the town.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s lab had a pungent chemical smell for days.

List4.Meaning: foolishly impractical; marked by lofty romantic ideals
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s quixotic idea of building a backyard zipline never left the drawing board.
List4.Friends Example: Ross’s quixotic plan to teach Ben Latin failed before it began.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s quixotic plan to sell homemade alarm clocks lasted two days.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s quixotic poetry phase lasted exactly three days.

List4.Meaning: occurring or recurring daily; commonplace; dull; repetitive
List4.Modern Family Example: Claire’s quotidian routine involved coffee, chaos, and complaints.
List4.Friends Example: Monica’s quotidian calendar included cleaning ‘fun’ every Saturday.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s quotidian routine included coffee, books, and more coffee.

List4.Meaning: to make or become thin, less dense; to refine

List4.Meaning: hidden; concealed; difficult to understand; obscure

List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Richard’s lectures sometimes veered into recondite territory.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s explanation of string theory was wildly recondite.

List4.Meaning: radiant; shiny; brilliant

List4.Gilmore Girls Example: The Stars Hollow festival had a sparse turnout thanks to a surprise blizzard.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s sparse compliments were so rare they became lore.

List4.Meaning: one who spends money wastefully

List4.Friends Example: Rachel was a total spendthrift during post-breakup shopping binges.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s spendthrift nature showed every time she passed an antique shop.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard’s spendthrift attitude at Comic-Con led to emergency Venmo requests.

List4.Meaning: not obvious; elusive; difficult to discern

List4.Friends Example: Ross gave a subtle nudge when Joey forgot his line—again.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s subtle disapproval was conveyed through a single raised eyebrow.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy gave a subtle glance that said, ‘Don’t start with Sheldon now.’

List4.Meaning: implied; not explicitly stated

List4.Meaning: brief and concise in wording

List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s terse comments made class discussions painfully efficient.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s terse emails were praised for their ‘concise cruelty.’

List4.Meaning: to publicly praise or promote

List4.Friends Example: Phoebe would tout her massage services even during coffee breaks.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai would tout Luke’s pancakes to any passing tourist.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Howard liked to tout his astronaut badge—even during takeout orders.

List4.Meaning: sharply perceptive; keen; penetrating

List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory’s trenchant critiques in debate club made even Paris sweat.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy’s trenchant comments about relationships stunned Sheldon into silence.

List4.Meaning: genuine; not false or hypocritical

List4.Friends Example: Joey’s unfeigned joy over pizza was unmatched.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s unfeigned love for coffee needed no explanation.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s unfeigned excitement over trains was oddly charming.

List4.Friends Example: Rachel’s justification for not returning the ring was untenable.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Kirk’s plan to turn the bookstore into a gym was completely untenable.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s idea of proposing with a drone was... utterly untenable.

List4.Meaning: to waver indecisively between one course of action or opinion and another; waver

List4.Friends Example: Monica vacillated between lasagna and quiche for the brunch menu.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai vacillated between sarcasm and sentiment when dealing with Emily.

List4.Meaning: multicolored; characterized by a variety of patches of different color

List4.Friends Example: Phoebe’s variegated scarf was ‘artistic’ and definitely blinding.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Miss Patty’s variegated scarves were legendary in Stars Hollow.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon rejected the variegated sweater Amy knitted for ‘lacking symmetry.’

List4.Meaning: annoyance; irritation

List4.Meaning: alertly watchful

List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke stayed vigilant during town meetings—ready to shut down Kirk’s schemes.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Amy stayed vigilant during Sheldon’s nap schedule to avoid wake-up wrath.

List4.Meaning: to use harsh condemnatory language; to abuse or censure severely or abusively; berate

List4.Friends Example: Monica vituperated Joey for using her fancy towels as napkins.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Emily vituperated the wait staff with precision—and a smile.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon vituperated his physics rival with elegant fury.

List4.Meaning: readily changing to a vapor; changeable; fickle; explosive
List4.Modern Family Example: Phil’s moods were as volatile as his real estate market updates.
List4.Friends Example: Rachel’s emotions were so volatile, even Phoebe brought tissues.
List4.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s mood during snow season was volatile—happy, then sleepy, then cranky.
List4.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s emotions were as volatile as his experiments.

List5.Modern Family Example: Phil was abashed when his magic trick went hilariously wrong at Lily’s party.
List5.Friends Example: Ross was abashed after tripping on stage at his lecture.
List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai was abashed when her phone rang during the town meeting—playing disco music.
List5.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon was abashed after misquoting a Star Trek episode.

List5.Modern Family Example: Claire’s abject expression after forgetting Luke’s school play was unforgettable.
List5.Friends Example: Joey’s abject attempt at French left even Phoebe speechless.
List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory felt abject after missing Lorelai’s graduation.
List5.Big Bang Theory Example: Raj’s abject heartbreak after Lucy left was hard to watch.

List5.Meaning: to deny oneself things; to reject; to renounce

List5.Meaning: sparing or moderate, especially in eating and drinking

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Rory was abstemious at Sookie’s dinner party, shocking everyone.

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Paris’s lecture on 17th-century politics was abstruse even to the professor.
List5.Big Bang Theory Example: Sheldon’s theories were so abstruse even the department chair was lost.

List5.Modern Family Example: Phil’s abysmal attempt at DIY plumbing flooded the kitchen.

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Lorelai’s financial situation in her twenties was abysmal.

List5.Meaning: to give in; to yield; to agree

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Luke was adroit at fixing coffee machines, unlike Taylor.

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: The advent of Rory’s first newspaper article made Lorelai beam with pride.

List5.Gilmore Girls Example: Taylor’s arrant interference at town meetings annoyed everyone.
